questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after presenting with elevated blood pressure during his last two visits within the past 6 months. After his last visit 2 months ago, he had opted to try controlling his hypertension with weight loss before starting medical therapy, but he has since been unable to lose any weight. He has hypercholesterolemia. His only medication is simvastatin. The patient is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb), BMI is 33 kg/m2. His pulse is 76/min and blood pressure is 154/90 mm Hg on the right arm and 155/93 mm Hg on the left arm. He agrees to start treatment with chlorthalidone. Which of the following serum laboratory changes is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics such as chlorthalidone can increase serum calcium levels. Other adverse effects include hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. The inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal tubule causes a net urine loss of positive ions such as Na+. This is compensated by renal tubular reabsorption of Ca2+ to maintain electrochemical balance. Thiazides can also be used for the management of osteoporosis and for the prevention of calcium kidney stones.

In patients with hypercholesterolemia and/or diabetes mellitus, the choice of antihypertensive medication requires careful consideration, since thiazide diuretics in combination with a wide range of drugs can exacerbate both conditions.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics such as chlorthalidone increase total serum cholesterol levels, mildly increase low-density lipoproteins, and increase triglyceride levels. Thiazides do not considerably change high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Both loop diuretics and thiazides such as chlorthalidone can cause hypokalemia by inhibition of Na+ reabsorption in the distal tubule and resultant increased K+ excretion in the late distal tubule and collecting tubule (via Na+-K+ exchangers); they do not increase potassium levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiazides and most diuretics decrease serum Na+. The diuretic effect of these drugs is due to the increase of Na+ in the renal tubule, which creates an osmotic gradient for fluid to be excreted in the urine.

E) INCORRECT:

Thiazides such as chlorthalidone worsen insulin resistance, which in turn increases glucose levels. Moreover, the plasma volume loss resulting from diuretics reflexively activates the sympathetic system, which also increases glucose levels by activating gluconeogenesis.

F) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics such as chlorthalidone increase (rather than decrease) uric acid levels, since they compete for the same binding site in the renal tubule transporters. Furthermore, the diuretic effect of thiazides leads to plasma volume depletion (dehydration) with subsequent hemoconcentration and increase of uric acid.
questions.hint: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic that acts by inhibiting NaCl reabsorption in the early distal tubule.

questions.text: Three days after being admitted to the hospital due to severe shortness of breath and receiving treatment for acute decompensated heart failure, a 82-year-old woman has difficulty understanding voices. An intravenous diuretic was used to treat her acute shortness of breath during her current admission. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, congestive heart failure, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Prior to admission to the hospital, her medications included ramipril, metoprolol, insulin, and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Whispered voice test shows bilateral hearing loss. Holding a 512 Hz tuning fork against the center of the forehead does not elicit lateralization. She has a positive Rinne test bilaterally. The diuretic most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms acts on which part of a nephron?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as acetazolamide act in the proximal convoluted tubule. They are used in the treatment of glaucoma, pseudotumor cerebri, metabolic alkalosis, and cysteine kidney stone prevention. They are not used in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure and are not associated with hearing loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Osmotic diuretics such as mannitol act predominantly in the straight segment of the proximal tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle. They are used for the treatment of cerebral edema and acute glaucoma. This class of diuretic is not used in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure and is not associated with hearing loss. Moreover, mannitol is rarely used in patients with underlying renal disease (as this patient), as the increased retention can lead to volume expansion and metabolic abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

This patient was most likely previously treated with intravenous furosemide, a loop diuretic used to treat acute decompensated heart failure that (like all loop diuretics) acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl--cotransporters on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Similar cotransporters are present in the stria vascularis of the inner ear, where they play a role in the regulation of the endolymphatic potential. As seen in this patient, high doses of loop diuretics, especially in patients with underlying renal insufficiency, carry a risk of sensorineural hearing loss due to structural damage of the cochlear stria vascularis.

Other important adverse effects of loop diuretics include metabolic abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, metabolic alkalosis), dehydration, and sulfonamide hypersensitivity.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics are a class of medications that act by inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters at the early distal tubule. They are used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic edema (e.g. secondary to CHF). However, thiazides are associated with metabolic, glucose, and lipid abnormalities, not with hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Potassium-sparing diuretics are a class of medications that act in the late distal tubule and cortical collecting ducts. They include aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) and epithelial sodium channel blockers (e.g., triamterene, amiloride). Binding of the medication to their respective targets leads to decreased Na+ reabsorption and K+ excretion. Although they are commonly used for the treatment of congestive heart failure, they are not the first line treatment for acute decompensated heart failure, nor are they associated with hearing loss.

F) INCORRECT:

Vasopressin (ADH) receptor antagonists (such as tolvaptan) act in the medullary collecting ducts. They may be used for the treatment of hyponatremia, although the evidence for their efficacy and safety is lacking. Tolvaptan inhibits the action of antidiuretic hormone, which normally increases water reabsorption in the collecting duct. It is neither used to treat acute decompensated heart failure, nor is associated with hearing loss.
questions.hint: This patient's positive Rinne test and lack of lateralization on Weber test is consistent with sensorineural hearing loss, a severe adverse effect of the diuretic she received.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of abdominal distention and mild diffuse abdominal discomfort for the past week. She has not had nausea, vomiting, fever, or chills. She was diagnosed with alcoholic liver cirrhosis 2 years ago. Examination shows a protruding, distended abdomen that is dull to percussion with a positive fluid wave. Ultrasonography shows mild to moderate ascites. Appropriate treatment of the patient's condition is started. Four days later, the patient experiences palpitations and chest pain at home. She is brought to the emergency department, where her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 182/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/50 mm Hg. An ECG shows ventricular tachycardia. Initial laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Na+

131 mEq/L


 K+

2.9 mEq/L


 Cl-

92 mEq/L


 Bicarbonate

34 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
42 mg/dL


 Creatinine

4.8 mg/dL


 Glucose
90 mg/dL


 Ca2+

8.1 mg/dL


 Mg2+

1.3 mEq/L


 Phosphate
4.7 mg/dL




Arterial Blood Gas



 pH

7.52


 pCO2

45 mm Hg


 pO2

90.2 mm Hg


She is successfully cardioverted to normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following treatments is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiazides, such as hydrochlorothiazide, are often used to manage ascites. Adverse effects may include hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, and hyperuricemia. However, hypercalcemia (not hypocalcemia) would be expected.

B) CORRECT:

Furosemide was likely prescribed to this patient to treat her ascites. Excess administration of furosemide can lead to a profound diuresis with water and electrolyte depletion, resulting in hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, hyponatremia, and ultimately acute kidney injury and metabolic alkalosis. Hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia can cause life-threatening arrhythmias, such as the ventricular tachycardia suffered by this patient. In addition to correcting this patient's electrolyte levels, management would also include prompt rehydration with intravenous fluids.

C) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor most commonly used for treating glaucoma and altitude sickness. Acetazolamide is not indicated for the treatment of ascites. While excess ingestion of acetazolamide would result in hypokalemia, it causes metabolic acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor used in the treatment of hypertension or heart failure but not in the management of ascites. Moreover, excess use of lisinopril would result in hyperkalemia as opposed to hypokalemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic used as a first-line treatment for ascites. However, excess use of spironolactone would result in hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis, not hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that is used in the treatment of cerebral edema or acute glaucoma but not for the management of ascites. Furthermore, excess mannitol would result in metabolic acidosis as opposed to metabolic alkalosis.
questions.hint: This patient received medical therapy for ascites. Additional side effects of the drug that caused her laboratory findings include hyperglycemia and ototoxicity.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening shortness of breath and progressive swelling of his legs for 1 week. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include amlodipine and pravastatin. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 113/70 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination shows bilateral coarse crackles. An S3 gallop is heard on auscultation. There is jugular venous distension and pitting edema of both ankles. He is admitted to the hospital, and treatment with intravenous bumetanide is initiated. Serum studies obtained 5 days after admission show:


Na+

138 mEq/L


Cl−

101 mEq/L


Mg2+

1.3 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
42 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.8 mg/dL


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.51


PCO2

52 mm Hg


PO2

60 mm Hg


HCO3-
33 mmol/L


Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The physiologic response to volume depletion includes activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which results in an increased serum aldosterone concentration. Aldosterone can further exacerbate metabolic derangement by increasing renal loss of K+ and H+, which results in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. In addition, volume depletion results in vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, which can lead to acute kidney injury, as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Flowchart summarizing the biochemical and physiological effects of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and current pharmacological inhibitors (overlay).

B) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics inhibit the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter, resulting in increased chloride excretion. This leads to an increase, not a decrease, in urine chloride concentration.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has signs of dehydration, prerenal azotemia, and an elevated BUN:creatinine ratio (> 20). These features indicate volume depletion. The physiologic response to volume depletion is an increase, not decrease, in serum renin concentration.

D) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics inhibit the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter, resulting in increased potassium excretion. This leads to a decreased, not increased, serum potassium concentration.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum vasopressin concentrations decrease in conditions of decreased serum osmolality (e.g., fluid overload). With the use of loop diuretics, however, both fluid and electrolytes are lost in equal proportion. Therefore, serum osmolality remains unchanged, and vasopressin concentrations would likely not be affected.
questions.hint: This patient has undergone treatment with a loop diuretic (bumetanide) for decompensated heart failure. The findings of his laboratory studies indicate prerenal azotemia and metabolic alkalosis. These features suggest volume depletion that has led to contraction alkalosis.

questions.text: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following drugs would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Torsemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the resorption of potassium in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It can also cause hypokalemia and would exacerbate the thiazide-induced hypokalemia seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine, like amlodipine, is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia. Moreover, the combination of drugs from the same class is not recommended for the treatment of hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist that acts centrally to decrease peripheral vascular resistance. Clonidine has no effect on potassium excretion and would not have prevented this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.

D) CORRECT:

Eplerenone is an effective adjunct antihypertensive medication in patients with treatment-resistant hypertension. In addition, the drug's potassium-sparing properties are useful in patients who develop hypokalemia due to the use of potassium-wasting diuretics (e.g., loop and thiazide diuretics). Eplerenone inhibits the effect of aldosterone and, therefore, decreases K+ excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine is a direct peripheral vasodilator that is used to decrease peripheral vascular resistance in patients with severe and/or treatment-resistant hypertension. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations of hypokalemia (e.g., muscle cramps, weakness, and U waves on ECG). Thiazide diuretics inhibit Na+ reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, which increases K+ excretion and can lead to hypokalemia.

questions.text: Three days after being admitted to the hospital for intensive pharmacological treatment of acute decompensated heart failure, a 77-year-old woman develops loss of hearing. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. Prior to admission, her medications included chlorthalidone, ramipril, metoprolol, insulin, and atorvastatin. Otoscopic examination shows no abnormalities. Whispered voice test shows severe, right-predominant hearing loss. Holding a 512 Hz tuning fork against the center of the forehead elicits lateralization to the left ear. She has a positive Rinne test bilaterally. The responsible offending agent most likely acts on which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as acetazolamide act in the proximal convoluted tubule. They are used in the treatment of glaucoma, pseudotumor cerebri, metabolic alkalosis, and cysteine kidney stone prevention. They are not used in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure and are not associated with hearing loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Osmotic diuretics such as mannitol act predominantly in the straight segment of the proximal tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle. They are used for the treatment of cerebral edema and acute glaucoma. This class of diuretic is not used in the treatment of acute decompensated heart failure and is not associated with hearing loss. Moreover, mannitol is rarely used in patients with underlying renal disease (as this patient), as the increased retention can lead to volume expansion and metabolic abnormalities.

C) CORRECT:

This patient was most likely previously treated with intravenous furosemide, a loop diuretic used to treat acute decompensated heart failure that (like all loop diuretics) acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl--cotransporters on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Similar cotransporters are present in the stria vascularis of the inner ear. As seen in this patient, high doses of loop diuretics, especially in patients with underlying renal insufficiency, carry a risk of sensorineural hearing loss.

Other important adverse effects of loop diuretics include metabolic abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, metabolic alkalosis), dehydration, and sulfonamide hypersensitivity.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics are a class of medications that act by inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters at the early distal tubule. This patient takes chlorthalidone, a thiazide used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic edema (e.g. secondary to CHF). However, thiazides are associated with metabolic, glucose, and lipid abnormalities, not with hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Potassium-sparing diuretics are a class of medications that act in the late distal tubule and cortical collecting ducts. They include aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone, eplerenone) and epithelial sodium channel blockers (e.g., triamterene, amiloride). Binding of the medication to their respective targets leads to decreased Na+ reabsorption and K+ excretion. Although they are used for the treatment of heart failure, they are not the first-line treatment for acute decompensated heart failure, nor are they associated with hearing loss.

F) INCORRECT:

Vasopressin (ADH) receptor antagonists (such as tolvaptan) act in the medullary collecting ducts. They may be used for the treatment of hyponatremia, although the evidence for their efficacy and safety is lacking. Tolvaptan inhibits the action of antidiuretic hormone, which normally increases water reabsorption in the collecting duct. It is neither used to treat acute decompensated heart failure, nor is associated with hearing loss.
questions.hint: This patient's positive Rinne test and lateralization on Weber test to her still intact ear is consistent with sensorineural hearing loss. Given the acute onset of symptoms shortly after initiating treatment, an adverse medication effect should be suspected.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman with dementia who resides in a nursing care facility is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after she was found to have ingested 20 pills of a drug that inhibits Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the distal convoluted tubule. Her blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



pH
Potassium
Calcium
Sodium



A
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased


B
Increased
decreased
increased
decreased


C
Decreased
increased
decreased
decreased


D
Decreased
decreased
normal
decreased


E
Decreased
increased
normal
decreased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Therapy with loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide), which inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the thick ascending loop of Henle, can lead to hyponatremia and hypokalemia due to increased urinary loss of Na+ and K+. In addition, the elevated luminal Na+ concentration in the late DCT and early collecting duct increases Na+ reabsorption in exchange for H+ excretion (i.e., increased serum pH) and further K+ excretion. Hypocalcemia can also occur because Ca2+ reabsorption through paracellular spaces in the loop of Henle is also decreased due to loss of the electrochemical gradient created by Na+ and Cl-. Thiazide diuretics, which this woman is likely to have ingested, result in a different set of electrolyte findings.

B) CORRECT:

Inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early DCT can cause hyponatremia due to increased Na+ excretion. Inhibition of Na+ reabsorption by the early DCT also increases Na+ delivery to the late DCT and early collecting tubule, which can cause hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis due to increased K+ and H+ secretion in exchange for luminal Na+ reabsorption. Hyponatremia and hypotension caused by diuretic overdose can also exacerbate this process through RAAS activation and aldosterone secretion. Thiazides also cause hypercalcemia. While the exact mechanism is unknown, it may be due in part to increased Ca2+ reabsorption at the proximal tubule as a result of increased extracellular fluid reabsorption in this segment. In addition, although thiazides inhibit reabsorption of Na+ in the early DCT, they appear to increase reabsorption of Ca2+. The other side effects of thiazide diuretics include hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

C) INCORRECT:

If an osmotic diuretic (e.g., mannitol) is administered in high doses or to individuals with pre-existing renal failure, it remains in circulation and increases plasma osmolality. Subsequently, water is released from cells in an attempt to correct plasma osmolality, resulting in dilutional hyponatremia, hypocalcemia, and metabolic acidosis. This shift of water into the extracellular compartment also causes an increase in the intracellular K+ concentration. Subsequently, K+ also moves into the extracellular compartment, causing hyperkalemia. However, osmotic diuretics act by increasing tubular fluid osmolarity; they do not inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the distal convoluted tubule. Thiazide diuretics, which this woman is likely to have ingested, result in a different set of electrolyte findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide) inhibit HCO3- reabsorption in the PCT, which can lead to decreased serum pH and hyponatremia due to renal sodium bicarbonate excretion. In addition, the elevated luminal Na+ concentration in the late DCT and early collecting duct increases Na+ reabsorption in exchange for K+ excretion, causing hypokalemia. Thiazide diuretics, which this woman is likely to have ingested, result in a different set of electrolyte findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., amiloride, spironolactone), which inhibit aldosterone receptors or epithelial Na+ channels in the late DCT and early collecting duct, can cause hyponatremia by inhibiting Na+ reabsorption. Inhibition of epithelial Na+ channels or aldosterone receptors in the late DCT and early collecting duct also decreases the concentration gradient responsible for K+ and H+ secretion, causing serum K+ and H+ concentrations to increase and pH to decrease. Potassium-sparing diuretics have no direct effect on calcium. Thiazide diuretics, which this woman is likely to have ingested, result in a different set of electrolyte findings.
questions.hint: Inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule is the mechanism of action of thiazide diuretics, which are used to treat hypertension, a common comorbidity in elderly patients. Patients with thiazide overdose present with polyuria, dehydration, hypotension, and potentially seizures and coma if high doses were ingested.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after presenting with elevated blood pressure readings during her last two visits. After her last visit 2 months ago, she tried controlling her hypertension with weight loss before starting medical therapy, but she has since been unable to lose any weight. Her pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 154/90 mm Hg on the right arm and 155/93 mm Hg on the left arm. She agrees to start treatment with a thiazide diuretic. In response to this treatment, which of the following is most likely to decrease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics increase rather than decrease serum uric acid levels by competing for the same binding site in the renal tubule transporters. Furthermore, the diuretic effect of thiazides leads to plasma volume depletion (dehydration) with subsequent hemoconcentration and increase of uric acid.

B) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) can increase serum calcium levels by decreasing the excretion of calcium in the urine. Other adverse effects include hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. The inhibition of renal Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal tubule causes a net urine loss of positive ions such as sodium. This is compensated by increased renal tubular reabsorption of calcium to maintain electrochemical balance. Thiazide diuretics are used mainly in the treatment of hypertension, but their effect on serum and urinary calcium concentration can also be used for management of osteoporosis and for prevention of calcium kidney stones.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiazide and most other diuretics decrease serum sodium concentration by increasing loss of sodium in the urine. The diuretic effect of thiazides is due to decreased reabsorption of renal Na+, which creates an osmotic gradient for fluid to be excreted in the urine.

D) INCORRECT:

Rather than decrease serum glucose levels, thiazide diuretics worsen insulin resistance, which in turn increases serum glucose levels. Moreover, the plasma volume loss resulting from diuretics reflexively activates the sympathetic system, which, in turn, also contributes to an increase in serum glucose levels by activating gluconeogenesis.

E) INCORRECT:

Rather than decrease lipid levels, thiazide diuretics increase total serum cholesterol levels, mildly increase low-density lipoproteins, and increase triglyceride levels. Thiazides do not have a substantial effect on high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Rather than decrease potassium excretion, thiazides and most other diuretics (except potassium-sparing agents) increase potassium excretion in the urine due to increased exchange of potassium for sodium via the Na+-K+ cotransporter in the late distal tubule. To avoid hypokalemia, thiazide diuretics may be combined with potassium-sparing diuretics.
questions.hint: Thiazide diuretics act by inhibiting Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal tubule of the kidney.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of severe headache and vomiting that started after she was hiking in the mountains at high altitude. She normally lives in a city that is close to sea level. Therapy is initiated with a drug that alkalinizes the urine. Which of the following is the most likely site of action of this drug in the kidney?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like acetazolamide enhance bicarbonate elimination in the proximal convoluted tubule. Bicarbonate diuresis results in urine alkalinization as well as normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. The latter drives compensatory respiratory alkalosis (hyperventilation) and thus speeds the acclimatization process of altitude sickness by increasing the blood oxygen concentration and reducing carbon dioxide levels.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

B) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics block the Na+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the ascending loop of Henle, which impairs the nephron's ability to reabsorb electrolytes and leads to diuresis. Loop diuretics decrease the urinary pH by increasing K+ and H+ secretion in the kidney; they are not used to treat altitude sickness.

C) INCORRECT:

The glomerulus forms the glomerular filtration barrier through which plasma components are filtered into the renal tubular system. Although certain drugs (NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors) can affect the perfusion of the glomeruli and GFR, and thereby indirectly influence the net filtration, absorption, or secretion of electrolytes in the nephron, there are no diuretics that act at the glomerulus.

D) INCORRECT:

Potassium-sparing diuretics reduce the reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. Although this class of diuretics can cause metabolic acidosis, and thus alkalinization of the urine, it is not used in the treatment of altitude sickness.

E) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics block the Na+/Cl- transporter in the early distal convoluted tubule, resulting in natriuresis and diuresis. Increased sodium excretion also increases potassium and hydrogen excretion, which acidifies the urine rather than alkalinizing it. This class of diuretic would not benefit this patient with altitude sickness.
questions.hint: This patient has symptoms of altitude sickness. The pharmaceutical treatment of choice for altitude sickness is acetazolamide, a urine alkalinizing agent.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled congestive heart failure comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. At his previous visit 4 months ago, a new drug was added to his treatment regimen. He reports that his dyspnea and peripheral edema have improved. His pulse is 70/min and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral, mildly tender enlargement of breast tissue. This patient's physical examination finding is most likely caused by a drug that acts at which of the following sites in the kidney?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act at the proximal convoluted tubule and promote diuresis. However, they are not used in the treatment of CHF and gynecomastia is not a known side effect. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are used to treat glaucoma, altitude sickness, and pseudotumor cerebri and their typical side effects include type 2 renal tubular acidosis, paresthesias, hyperammonemia, hypokalemia, increased risk of calcium phosphate stones, and hypersensitivity reaction (sulfa drug).

B) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers inhibit sympathetic activation of beta-adrenergic receptors in various parts of the body, including the juxtaglomerular apparatus, and are used to treat heart failure. Adverse effects of beta blockers include erectile dysfunction, exacerbation of COPD or asthma, bradycardia, and sleep alteration. Gynecomastia is not a side effect of beta blockers.

C) INCORRECT:

Drugs that act on renal afferent arterioles include angiotensin receptor blockers (efferent arteriole dilation) and nesiritide (efferent arteriole constriction). Both these drugs are used to treat heart failure (ARBs to prevent cardiac remodeling; nesiritide to treat fluid overload in acute decompensated heart failure) but neither of these drugs causes gynecomastia. Side effects associated with nesiritide and ARBs include hypotension and renal insufficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics act at the early distal convoluted tubule and are used to treat heart failure. They are associated with side effects such as metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypercalcemia, hyperuricemia, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hypersensitivity reaction (sulfa drug). Thiazides do not cause gynecomastia.

E) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics act at the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and are used to treat heart failure. Side effects of loop diuretics include metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperuricemia, ototoxicity and interstitial nephritis, and hypersensitivity reaction (with sulfa drugs such as furosemide, bumetanide, and torsemide). Gynecomastia is not a known side effect of loop diuretics.

F) CORRECT:

Spironolactone, which is a competitive aldosterone receptors antagonist, acts on the principal cells in the cortical collecting ducts. It is used to reduce morbidity and mortality in patients with heart failure. Spironolactone inhibits the binding of androgens to their receptors as well as the activity of enzymes involved in androgen synthesis (e.g., 17,20-desmolase, 17α-hydroxylase). It also increases the peripheral conversion of testosterone to estradiol and displaces estradiol from SHBG. This combination of antiandrogenic and pro-estrogenic effects can cause gynecomastia and impotence in men.

Eplerenone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist with a greater specificity for the mineralocorticoid receptor than spironolactone; it has a lower incidence of endocrine side effects.
questions.hint: Gynecomastia is a classic side effect of spironolactone, which is used in the management of congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after an episode of lightheadedness during which he almost fainted. He was doing yard work when he began feeling dizzy and had to lie down. Earlier in the day, he was started on lisinopril. On arrival, he is fully oriented. His pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 92/60 mm Hg. Serum electrolytes are within normal limits. ECG shows no evidence of ischemia. Concurrent treatment with which of the following agents most likely predisposed the patient to this episode?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atorvastatin is a type of statin, or HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, used to treat hypercholesterolemia. This drug inhibits cholesterol synthesis in the liver. Although atorvastatin would have interactions with other lipid-lowering agents and CYP3A4 inhibitors, it has no significant interactions with antihypertensives like lisinopril.

B) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen is an NSAID that reversibly inhibits the enzymes COX-1 and COX-2, resulting in an antiinflammatory effect. Because NSAIDs reduce the ACE inhibitor's kinin-mediated synthesis of prostaglandins, ibuprofen would decrease lisinopril's hypotensive effect rather than enhance it.

C) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics such as hydrochlorothiazide act by inhibition of the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule, which results in blood pressure reduction. In the treatment of hypertension, thiazide diuretics are used as first-line agents. When additional antihypertensives such as ACE inhibitors are initiated, patients who already take other antihypertensive medications such as diuretics or are volume-depleted are at higher risk for first-dose hypotension.

While this patient has normal electrolytes, possible side effects of thiazide diuretic include hypokalemia, hyponatremia, and hypomagnesemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lithium is used to treat bipolar disorders and has numerous adverse effects and interactions with other drugs. ACE inhibitors can lead to increased lithium reabsorption in the proximal tubules and increased risk of lithium toxicity, which would present with tremor, ataxia, vomiting, diarrhea, and other neuropsychiatric impairments but not hypotension as this patient is experiencing.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is a combination antibiotic that has a broad spectrum of activity against many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. It may interact with ACE inhibitors like lisinopril by synergistically increasing the risk of hyperkalemia. However, TMP/SMX has no direct effect on blood pressure and would not lead to hypotension.

F) INCORRECT:

Metformin is a biguanide used as a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus to increase insulin sensitivity and decrease gluconeogenesis. It has interactions with sulfonylureas and is contraindicated before the use of contrast medium because of the increased risk of lactic acidosis. However, metformin has no known interaction with ACE inhibitors.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a symptomatic hypotensive episode after initiating lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor). This effect is referred to as first-dose hypotension and is particularly common if two antihypertensive agents that work synergistically are given at the same time.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of progressive shortness of breath, lower extremity edema, and a 4-kg (9-lb) weight gain. She has ischemic cardiomyopathy and rheumatoid arthritis. Her respirations are 27/min. Examination shows pitting edema of the lower extremities and crackles over both lower lung fields. Therapy is initiated with intravenous furosemide. After 2 hours, urine output is minimal. Concomitant treatment with which of the following drugs is most likely to have contributed to treatment failure?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sulfasalazine can be used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Sulfasalazine and furosemide are both sulfa drugs; therefore, patients who are allergic to either of these drugs may also be allergic to the other. This patient, however, does not show symptoms of a sulfa-induced allergy (e.g., skin rash, fever, headache). Sulfasalazine does not interfere with the therapeutic effect of furosemide.

B) CORRECT:

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as diclofenac are commonly used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. NSAIDs adversely affect renal function by inhibiting renal synthesis of prostaglandins, which help maintain renal perfusion in dehydrated states. Decreased prostaglandin synthesis (e.g., of prostaglandin E1) counteracts the therapeutic effect of furosemide and can lead to hypoperfusion of the kidneys and reduced GFR.

This patient's symptoms at the time of presentation are likely due to acute exacerbation of ischemic cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone can be used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Because of prednisone's mineralocorticoid potency, it can increase both sodium reabsorption and the excretion of potassium and hydrogen in the renal tubule. Therefore, prednisone may enhance the potassium-wasting effect of loop diuretics and increase the risk of hypokalemia. However, treatment with prednisone would not explain the decreased urine output seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Infliximab can be used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. However, infliximab does not interfere with the therapeutic effect of furosemide. While infliximab has no major effect on the kidney, it may predispose to infection, including reactivation of latent tuberculosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Furosemide and digoxin are frequently used together to treat ischemic cardiomyopathy. Patients taking both drugs should be monitored closely as loop diuretics can lead to hypokalemia, which subsequently increases digoxin binding to the Na+/K+-ATPases in cardiomyocytes, predisposing patients to digoxin toxicity (e.g., arrhythmias). However, treatment with digoxin would not explain the decreased urine output seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, inhibit the Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and stimulate prostaglandin E (PGE) release (prostaglandins maintain renal blood flow by inducing vasodilation of the afferent arterioles). Agents that inhibit prostaglandin synthesis counteract this effect and decrease the efficacy of loop diuretics.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of severe left eye pain, blurred vision, nausea, and vomiting. She has had an upper respiratory tract infection for the past 2 days and has been taking phenylephrine to control her symptoms. Examination shows a rock-hard, injected left globe and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil on the left. Gonioscopy shows that the iris meets the cornea at an angle of 10° (N = 20–45°). Systemic pharmacotherapy is initiated with a drug that decreases the secretion of aqueous humor from the ciliary epithelium. The next day, her serum potassium concentration is slightly decreased. Which of the following additional adverse effects is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epithelial keratopathy is a possible adverse effect of the topical prostaglandin latanoprost, which is a first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma. This patient, however, has acute closed-angle glaucoma and is being treated with a systemic medication. In addition, latanoprost increases aqueous humor drainage through the uveoscleral pathway, whereas this patient was treated with a medication that decreases the secretion of aqueous humor by the ciliary epithelium. Finally, latanoprost does not affect potassium levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Xerostomia is associated with drugs that suppress secretion from the salivary glands, like α2-adrenergic agonists. Apraclonidine, a topical ophthalmic α2-adrenergic agonist, is often used to treat acute angle-closure glaucoma by decreasing synthesis of aqueous humor by the ciliary epithelium, similar to the medication used here. However, this patient is receiving systemic pharmacotherapy and α2-adrenergic agonists do not cause a decrease in potassium levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers (e.g., timolol) and parasympathomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine) can cause bradycardia. While these medications can be used in the treatment of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, they are given as topical formulations whereas this patient is receiving systemic treatment. While beta-blockers also improve the symptoms of glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis, they are associated with hyperkalemia, in contrast to this patient who developed hypokalemia after starting the medication. Parasympathomimetics, on the other hand, increase aqueous humor drainage via ciliary muscle contraction and trabecular meshwork opening

D) CORRECT:

Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, improves the symptoms of glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor synthesis by the ciliary epithelium. It is a first-line treatment for acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, which can be precipitated by mydriasis due to darkness, fear, stress, or certain medications (e.g., phenylephrine). However, acetazolamide can impair bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, which may cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis as a result of type 2 renal tubular acidosis. Other important adverse effects of acetazolamide include hypokalemia, sulfa allergy, and hyperammonemia with paresthesias.
Image Description:

PGF2α analogues (e.g., latanoprost)
– Reduce outflow resistance of trabecular meshwork
– Increase uveoscleral outflow by relaxing ciliary muscle and disrupting turnover of extracellular matrix

β-blockers (e.g., timolol): diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPase

α2 agonists (e.g., brimonidine)
– Reduce episcleral venous pressure
– Diminish aqueous humor production by inhibiting Na+/K+ ATPase

Cholinomimetics (e.g., pilocarpine)
– Widen trabecular meshwork via ciliary muscle activation
– Open up the iridocorneal angle by activating the iris sphincter muscle (miosis)

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (CAI; e.g., acetazolamide): diminish aqueous humor production

Rho-kinase inhibitors (e.g., netarsudil)
– Increase trabecular outflow
– Lower episcleral venous pressure
– Decrease aqueous humor production by increasing noradrenergic transmission

E) INCORRECT:

Diaphoresis can be an adverse effect of parasympathomimetic drugs, including the topical ophthalmic formulations (e.g., pilocarpine) given in the treatment of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. This patient, however, is receiving systemic treatment. In addition, parasympathomimetics increase aqueous humor drainage via ciliary muscle contraction and trabecular meshwork opening, whereas this patient was treated with a medication that decreases the secretion of aqueous humor by the ciliary epithelium.
questions.hint: The patient's sudden-onset eye pain and blurred vision along with a rock-hard left globe on exam are highly suggestive of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. A narrow iridocorneal angle confirms the diagnosis. The patient received treatment with acetazolamide.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 6-hour history of severe headache, nausea, and 1 episode of vomiting. On arrival, she is lethargic and oriented only to self. Her pulse is 50/min, respirations are 8/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. Examination shows medial deviation of the left globe and ecchymoses of the upper eyelids. Appropriate pharmacotherapy with an intravenous drug is initiated, and the patient's urine output subsequently increases. The patient is at greatest risk of which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DRESS) is associated with sulfa drugs, which includes diuretics such as furosemide, acetazolamide, and hydrochlorothiazide. Furosemide can be used as an adjunct in cases of acutely increased intracranial pressure but it is not the first-line drug. Acetazolamide is used to treat glaucoma and idiopathic intracranial hypertension but is not indicated for acutely increased intracranial pressure. Thiazide diuretics are not indicated for the treatment of elevated intracranial pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperuricemia can arise following treatment with hydrochlorothiazide but is not associated with mannitol. Thiazide diuretics are not indicated for the treatment of elevated intracranial pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

Tinnitus is a potential side effect of acetazolamide or furosemide but is not a side effect of mannitol. Furosemide can be used as an adjunct in cases of acutely increased intracranial pressure but it is not the first-line drug. Acetazolamide is used to treat glaucoma and idiopathic intracranial hypertension but is not indicated for acutely increased intracranial pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Mannitol infusions tend to decrease intraocular pressure by reducing the volume of vitreous humor, which is why they are used for treating acute angle closure glaucoma. Since increased intraocular pressure is a potential side effect of corticosteroids, they are not recommended in cases of elevated intracranial pressure.

E) CORRECT:

Mannitol causes an increase in plasma osmolality, resulting in osmotic shifts of water into the intravascular space. This effect decreases cerebral edema but can lead to iatrogenic volume overload and pulmonary edema. Risk factors for this side effect of mannitol include very high doses and a low glomerular filtration rate.
questions.hint: The patient presents with nausea, vomiting, headache, and a decreased level of consciousness. Examination shows the Cushing triad (bradycardia, respiratory depression, and hypertension), cranial nerve VI palsy, and spontaneous bruising of the upper eyelids. These are classic features of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP), which can be treated with mannitol, an osmotic diuretic.

questions.text:
A new drug is developed that inhibits the sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely to occur after 2 days of therapy with this drug?



Serum pH
Jugular venous pressure (JVP)



A
No change
increased


B
No change
no change


C
Decreased
decreased


D
Increased
decreased


E
Decreased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

No change in pH and an increase in JVP would be observed with the use of an osmotic diuretic such as mannitol. This class of diuretics increases the osmotic gradient within blood vessels and tubules to pull water into the intravascular space. The increase in blood and tubular fluid osmolarity subsequently leads to an increase in urine outflow. This mechanism makes these diuretics very effective at decreasing intracranial pressure and intraocular pressure. In contrast, the drug in question here inhibits the Na-K-Cl cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle.

B) INCORRECT:

No change in pH or JVP would be expected after administration of a K+-sparing diuretic such as spironolactone. Because this class of diuretics has a relatively weak effect on overall Na+ balance, a change in intravascular volume (of which JVP is a marker) would not be expected. Furthermore, the inhibitory effect on K+ excretion can indirectly reduce H+ excretion, but this would not result in a change in serum pH because of renal compensation at the proximal convoluted tubule.

C) INCORRECT:

A decrease in pH and in JVP would be seen in patients taking a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor such as acetazolamide. This class of diuretics inhibits the transport of bicarbonate out of the proximal convoluted tubule into the interstitium, which leads to decreased Na+ reabsorption at this site and therefore greater loss of Na+ (decrease fluid volume/JVP), bicarbonate (decrease in pH), and water in the urine. In contrast, the drug in question here inhibits the Na-K-Cl cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle.

D) CORRECT:

Increased serum pH and decreased JVP occur when the Na-K-Cl cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle is inhibited. Inhibiting this cotransporter impairs Na+ reabsorption, which causes relative hypovolemia. The typical response is contraction alkalosis (increased serum pH, reduced JVP). The inability to reabsorb K+ in the ascending loop also results in a higher luminal concentration in the collecting tubule, where K+ ions are absorbed at the expense of H+, further contributing to metabolic alkalosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum pH and increased JVP would be observed in a patient taking a drug that stimulates the Na-K-Cl cotransporter. Stimulating this transporter increases the reabsorption of Na+, K+, and Cl-, as well as Mg2+ and Ca2+ (via the positive lumen potential created by K+ shifts). Increased K+ reabsorption (with concomitant H+ reabsorption) leads to metabolic acidosis, and increased Na+ reabsorption increases fluid retention (which increases JVP).
questions.hint: This experimental drug has a mechanism of action that is identical to loop diuretics such as furosemide, torsemide, and bumetanide.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-hour history of nausea, right flank pain, and hematuria. The pain is 7 out of 10 in intensity. He has had recurrent episodes of nephrolithiasis since the age of 14 years. Three years ago, he underwent ureterorenoscopy for a kidney stone measuring 16 mm. Microscopic examination of the stone showed hexagonal crystals. He has a family history of cystinuria. On physical examination, his abdomen is soft without guarding. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a radiopaque stone in the right ureter measuring 5 mm. The patient is advised to increase his fluid intake and is started on acetazolamide. Which of the following is most likely to decrease following treatment with this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide increases urine pH. Carbonic anhydrase inhibition increases bicarbonate concentration in the tubular lumen and alkalinizes urine. Continuous loss of bicarbonate can eventually lead to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (proximal renal tubular acidosis).

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide increases renal bicarbonate excretion. Carbonic anhydrase inhibition leads to the inhibition of the Na+/H+ antiporter on the luminal side of PCT cells. As a result, sodium and bicarbonate remain in the tubular lumen and are excreted.

C) CORRECT:

Acetazolamide decreases renal ammonia excretion by indirectly increasing its reabsorption in the nephron. By inhibiting carbonic anhydrase, acetazolamide increases renal excretion of bicarbonate, sodium, water, and potassium. Increased bicarbonate excretion alkalinizes urine, which promotes the reabsorption of ammonia. Other side effects of acetazolamide include sulfonamide allergy and hyperchloremic, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. In addition to reducing the risk of kidney stones in patients with cystinuria, acetazolamide is used to treat altitude sickness and idiopathic intracranial hypertension, lower intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma, and reduce drug-induced edema.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide moderately increases urine output. Carbonic anhydrase inhibition leads to increased sodium concentration in the tubular lumen, which promotes water excretion and increases the volume in the proximal convoluted tubule. Most of the water is reabsorbed in the distal segments of the nephron, especially in the loop of Henle, which reduces the diuretic effect of acetazolamide. As a result, it is not commonly used for the treatment of volume overload (e.g., as in congestive heart failure or pulmonary edema).

E) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide increases renal potassium excretion. Carbonic anhydrase inhibition leads to increased sodium concentration in the tubular lumen. As it reaches the collecting duct, sodium is reabsorbed via epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in exchange for potassium excretion via the ATP-dependent potassium channel (ROMK channel), which can lead to hypokalemia. Potassium-sparing diuretics such as spironolactone, eplerenone, triamterene, and amiloride cause decreased potassium excretion.
questions.hint: Acetazolamide works by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, which leads to increased cystine solubility.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes complicated by diabetic kidney disease with proteinuria presents for follow-up.
His long-standing medications include atorvastatin 20 mg daily, hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily, and metformin 1000 mg twice daily. He is not currently taking an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor or an angiotensin-receptor blocker, having previously developed angioedema while taking ramipril. He recently started canagliflozin 100 mg daily, as prescribed by his nephrologist, to reduce progression of his chronic kidney disease. He reports good tolerance and adherence with his medications. He checks his blood pressure regularly at home and reports average readings of 110/70 mm Hg.
Today, his glycated hemoglobin level is 7.3%, and his blood pressure is 99/65 mm Hg. He reports mild light-headedness with standing.
Recent laboratory testing yielded the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
34
10–20


Serum creatinine (mg/dL)
1.4
0.8–1.3


Estimated glomerular filtration rate (mL/min/1.73 m2)
50
≥60


Random blood glucose (mg/dL)
180
<140


Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (mg/g)
320
<30


Serum electrolyte levels including sodium, potassium, and chloride were all within normal limits.
Which one of the following next steps in management is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Increase the dose of canagliflozin to 300 mg daily
Continue the current medication regimen without changes

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient recently started taking canagliflozin, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor, while also taking a thiazide diuretic. He now has signs of hypovolemia and hypotension. The diuretic should be stopped and the other medications continued.

The Nonglycemic Effects of SGLT-2 Inhibitors

SGLT-2 inhibitors are antidiabetic agents that block SGLT-2 in the proximal renal tubule, promoting urinary glucose excretion and leading to improved glycemic control. These agents are also associated with osmotic diuresis and natriuresis, with resulting reductions in plasma volume and both systolic and diastolic blood pressure. These effects may explain some of the nonglycemic benefits seen with SGLT-2 inhibitors, including beneficial effects on heart failure and kidney disease progression, as shown in multiple trials.

When initiating SGLT-2 inhibitors, patients should be counseled about the risks of hypovolemia and intravascular volume contraction, especially if they are already receiving diuretic agents. In those with well-controlled blood pressure on low doses of a thiazide diuretic, it may be reasonable to preemptively stop the diuretic when initiating the SGLT-2 inhibitor; if this is not done, then the diuretic should be stopped if evidence of hypovolemia develops.

Patients should also be counseled to hold their SGLT-2 inhibitor in the presence of any additional hypovolemia-provoking factors, such as gastrointestinal illnesses. These agents are also frequently held before major surgery.

Key learning point: When a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor is initiated in a patient with well-controlled blood pressure on a low-dose diuretic, the diuretic should be discontinued to reduce the risk of hypovolemia and hypotension.

B) INCORRECT:

There are no indications to discontinue the patient’s metformin, which he is tolerating at an appropriate dose. A dose reduction would be needed only if the estimated glomerular filtration rate dropped below 45 mL/min/1.73 m2.

C) INCORRECT:

Given this patient’s hypovolemia and hypotension, he should stop the diuretic. If the hypovolemia resolves in the future, one may consider increasing the dose of the SGLT-2 inhibitor to extract the agent’s maximal glycemic and nonglycemic benefits; however, this would not be appropriate in the presence of hypovolemia and hypotension.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient recently started taking canagliflozin, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor, while also taking a thiazide diuretic. He now has signs of hypovolemia and hypotension. The diuretic should be stopped and the other medications continued.

E) INCORRECT:

Stopping this patient’s SGLT-2 inhibitor and initiating glipizide would not be appropriate. Glipizide will lower the patient’s blood glucose further, increasing his risk for hypoglycemia, and it will not provide him any additional renal protection.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after an episode of lightheadedness during which he almost fainted. Earlier in the day, he was started on lisinopril. On arrival, he is fully oriented. His pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg. ECG shows no evidence of ischemia. Concurrent treatment with which of the following agents most likely predisposed the patient to this hypotensive episode?

A) INCORRECT:

Atorvastatin is a type of statin, or HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, used to treat hypercholesterolemia. This drug inhibits cholesterol synthesis in the liver. Although atorvastatin would have interactions with other lipid-lowering agents and CYP3A4 inhibitors, it has no significant interactions with antihypertensives like lisinopril.
