In the treatment of hypertension, thiazide diuretics are used as first-line agents. When additional antihypertensives such as ACE inhibitors are initiated, patients who already take other antihypertensive medications such as diuretics or are volume-depleted are at higher risk for first-dose hypotension.

Possible side effects of thiazide diuretic include hypokalemia, hyponatremia, and hypomagnesemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lithium is used to treat bipolar disorders and has numerous adverse effects and interactions with other drugs. ACE inhibitors can lead to increased lithium reabsorption in the proximal tubules and increased risk of lithium toxicity, which would present with tremor, ataxia, vomiting, diarrhea, and other neuropsychiatric impairments but not hypotension as this patient is experiencing.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is a combination antibiotic that has a broad spectrum of activity against many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. It may interact with ACE inhibitors like lisinopril by synergistically increasing the risk of hyperkalemia. However, TMP/SMX has no direct effect on blood pressure and would not lead to hypotension.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a symptomatic hypotensive episode after initiating lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor). This effect is referred to as first-dose hypotension and is particularly common if two antihypertensive agents that work synergistically are given at the same time.

questions.text: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the office because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography shows sinus rhythm with prominent U waves in the precordial leads. The addition of which of the following drugs would most likely have prevented this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Torsemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the resorption of potassium in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It can also cause hypokalemia and would exacerbate the thiazide-induced hypokalemia seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine, like amlodipine, is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia. Moreover, the combination of drugs from the same class is not recommended for the treatment of hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist that acts centrally to decrease peripheral vascular resistance. Clonidine has no effect on potassium excretion and would not have prevented this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.

D) CORRECT:

Eplerenone is an effective adjunct antihypertensive medication in patients with treatment-resistant hypertension. In addition, the drug's potassium-sparing properties are useful in patients who develop hypokalemia due to the use of potassium-wasting diuretics (e.g., loop and thiazide diuretics). Eplerenone inhibits the effect of aldosterone and, therefore, decreases K+ excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 77/min
– Normal cardiac axis
– Prolonged PR interval (~220 ms)
– ST-segment depression in I, II, and V2 to V6 (example indicated by red overlay in V2 zoom box)
– T-wave flattening in the limb leads
– Prominent U waves in the precordial leads, with fusion of the T and U waves (examples indicated by purple and green overlays respectively). The P waves in these leads (example indicated by blue overlay) are also mostly buried in the U waves.

These findings are characteristic of severe hypokalemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine is a direct peripheral vasodilator that is used to decrease peripheral vascular resistance in patients with severe and/or treatment-resistant hypertension. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations of hypokalemia (e.g., muscle cramps, weakness, and U waves on ECG). Thiazide diuretics inhibit Na+ reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, which increases K+ excretion and can lead to hypokalemia.

questions.text:
A new drug is developed that inhibits the sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely to occur after 2 days of therapy with this drug?



Serum pH
Jugular venous pressure (JVP)



A
No change
increased


B
No change
no change


C
Decreased
decreased


D
Increased
decreased


E
Decreased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

No change in pH and an increase in JVP would be observed with the use of an osmotic diuretic such as mannitol. This class of diuretics increases the osmotic gradient within blood vessels and tubules to pull water into the intravascular space. The increase in blood and tubular fluid osmolarity subsequently leads to an increase in urine outflow. This mechanism makes these diuretics very effective at decreasing intracranial pressure and intraocular pressure. In contrast, the drug in question here inhibits the Na-K-Cl cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle.

B) INCORRECT:

No change in pH or JVP would be expected after administration of a K+-sparing diuretic such as spironolactone. Because this class of diuretics has a relatively weak effect on overall Na+ balance, a change in intravascular volume (of which JVP is a marker) would not be expected. Furthermore, the inhibitory effect on K+ excretion can indirectly reduce H+ excretion, but this would not result in a change in serum pH because of renal compensation at the proximal convoluted tubule.

C) INCORRECT:

A decrease in pH and in JVP would be seen in patients taking a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor such as acetazolamide. This class of diuretics inhibits the transport of bicarbonate out of the proximal convoluted tubule into the interstitium, which leads to decreased Na+ reabsorption at this site and therefore greater loss of Na+ (decrease fluid volume/JVP), bicarbonate (decrease in pH), and water in the urine. In contrast, the drug in question here inhibits the Na-K-Cl cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle.

D) CORRECT:

Increased serum pH and decreased JVP occur when the Na-K-Cl cotransporter in the ascending loop of Henle is inhibited. Inhibiting this cotransporter impairs Na+ reabsorption, which causes relative hypovolemia. The typical response is contraction alkalosis (increased serum pH, reduced JVP). The inability to reabsorb K+ in the ascending loop also results in a higher luminal concentration in the collecting tubule, where K+ ions are absorbed at the expense of H+, further contributing to metabolic alkalosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum pH and increased JVP would be observed in a patient taking a drug that stimulates the Na-K-Cl cotransporter. Stimulating this transporter increases the reabsorption of Na+, K+, and Cl-, as well as Mg2+ and Ca2+ (via the positive lumen potential created by K+ shifts). Increased K+ reabsorption (with concomitant H+ reabsorption) leads to metabolic acidosis, and increased Na+ reabsorption increases fluid retention (which increases JVP).
questions.hint: This experimental drug has a mechanism of action that is identical to loop diuretics such as furosemide, torsemide, and bumetanide.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination after presenting with elevated blood pressure during his last two visits within the past 6 months. His blood pressure is 154/90 mm Hg on the right arm and 155/93 mm Hg on the left arm. He agrees to start treatment with a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following serum laboratory changes is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics can increase serum calcium levels. Other adverse effects include hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. The inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal tubule causes a net urine loss of positive ions such as Na+. This is compensated by renal tubular reabsorption of Ca2+ to maintain electrochemical balance. Thiazides can also be used for the management of osteoporosis and for the prevention of calcium kidney stones.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics increase total serum cholesterol levels, mildly increase low-density lipoproteins, and increase triglyceride levels. Thiazides do not considerably change high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Both loop diuretics and thiazides can cause hypokalemia by inhibition of Na+ reabsorption in the distal tubule and resultant increased K+ excretion in the late distal tubule and collecting tubule (via Na+-K+ exchangers); they do not increase potassium levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiazides and most diuretics decrease serum Na+. The diuretic effect of these drugs is due to the increase of Na+ in the renal tubule, which creates an osmotic gradient for fluid to be excreted in the urine.

E) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics increase (rather than decrease) uric acid levels, since they compete for the same binding site in the renal tubule transporters. Furthermore, the diuretic effect of thiazides leads to plasma volume depletion (dehydration) with subsequent hemoconcentration and increase of uric acid.
questions.hint: Thiazide diuretics act by inhibiting NaCl reabsorption in the early distal tubule.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe pain, redness, and swelling of his right first metatarsophalangeal joint. He has chronic systolic heart failure and was recently started on a new medication. He has no prior history of inflammatory arthritis. Vital signs are stable (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Uric acid
577 μmol/L
200 - 410 μmol/L


Joint aspiration: Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals
Which medication most likely contributed to his current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, does not significantly affect uric acid metabolism or renal urate handling. It is not associated with hyperuricemia or gout flares, unlike diuretics that reduce uric acid clearance.

B) INCORRECT:

Carvedilol, a non-selective beta-blocker, may cause mild increases in serum uric acid due to reduced renal blood flow, but this effect is minimal and unlikely to trigger an acute gout flare. Diuretics are more commonly associated with hyperuricemia and gout.

C) CORRECT:

Furosemide, a loop diuretic, decreases renal uric acid clearance by causing volume depletion, which enhances proximal tubular reabsorption of urate. This can lead to increased serum uric acid levels, precipitating monosodium urate crystal formation. These needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals are diagnostic for gout, which presents with acute pain, redness, and swelling of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. Furosemide is associated with diuretic-induced hyperuricemia, contributing to gouty arthritis.

Key learning point: Loop diuretics like Lasix can increase uric acid levels and potentially trigger gout attacks in susceptible individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist used in heart failure. It does not typically decrease uric acid clearance or increase serum uric acid levels, unlike loop and thiazide diuretics, which can predispose to gout.

questions.text: You are seeing a 43-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by his wife after experiencing lightheadedness and near-syncope. He was started on lisinopril earlier today. On arrival, he is fully oriented. His pulse is 100/min and blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg. ECG shows no evidence of ischemia. Concurrent treatment with which one of the following agents most likely predisposed him to this hypotensive episode?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is a combination antibiotic that has a broad spectrum of activity against many gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. It may interact with ACE inhibitors like lisinopril by synergistically increasing the risk of hyperkalemia. However, TMP/SMX has no direct effect on blood pressure and would not lead to hypotension.

B) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen is an NSAID that reversibly inhibits the enzymes COX-1 and COX-2, resulting in an antiinflammatory effect. Because NSAIDs reduce the ACE inhibitor's kinin-mediated synthesis of prostaglandins, ibuprofen would decrease lisinopril's hypotensive effect rather than enhance it.

C) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics such as hydrochlorothiazide act by inhibition of the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule, which results in blood pressure reduction. In the treatment of hypertension, thiazide diuretics are used as first-line agents. When additional antihypertensives such as ACE inhibitors are initiated, patients who already take other antihypertensive medications such as diuretics or are volume-depleted are at higher risk for first-dose hypotension.

Possible side effects of thiazide diuretic include hypokalemia, hyponatremia, and hypomagnesemia.

Key learning point: Initiating ACE inhibitors in patients already taking thiazide diuretics increases the risk of first-dose hypotension due to additive blood pressure–lowering and volume-depleting effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Lithium is used to treat bipolar disorders and has numerous adverse effects and interactions with other drugs. ACE inhibitors can lead to increased lithium reabsorption in the proximal tubules and increased risk of lithium toxicity, which would present with tremor, ataxia, vomiting, diarrhea, and other neuropsychiatric impairments but not hypotension as this patient is experiencing.

E) INCORRECT:

Atorvastatin is a type of statin, or HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor, used to treat hypercholesterolemia. This drug inhibits cholesterol synthesis in the liver. Although atorvastatin would have interactions with other lipid-lowering agents and CYP3A4 inhibitors, it has no significant interactions with antihypertensives like lisinopril.
questions.hint: This patient presents with a symptomatic hypotensive episode after initiating lisinopril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE inhibitor). This effect is referred to as first-dose hypotension and is particularly common if two antihypertensive agents that work synergistically are given at the same time.

questions.text: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to your clinic because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination is normal. Electrocardiography shows sinus rhythm with prominent U waves in the precordial leads. The addition of which one of the following drugs would most likely have prevented his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Eplerenone is an effective adjunct antihypertensive medication in patients with treatment-resistant hypertension. In addition, the drug's potassium-sparing properties are useful in patients who develop hypokalemia due to the use of potassium-wasting diuretics (e.g., loop and thiazide diuretics). Eplerenone inhibits the effect of aldosterone and, therefore, decreases K+ excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

Key learning point: Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing antihypertensive that can prevent hypokalemia caused by thiazide or loop diuretics.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 77/min
– Normal cardiac axis
– Prolonged PR interval (~220 ms)
– ST-segment depression in I, II, and V2 to V6 (example indicated by red overlay in V2 zoom box)
– T-wave flattening in the limb leads
– Prominent U waves in the precordial leads, with fusion of the T and U waves (examples indicated by purple and green overlays respectively). The P waves in these leads (example indicated by blue overlay) are also mostly buried in the U waves.

These findings are characteristic of severe hypokalemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydralazine is a direct peripheral vasodilator that is used to decrease peripheral vascular resistance in patients with severe and/or treatment-resistant hypertension. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist that acts centrally to decrease peripheral vascular resistance. Clonidine has no effect on potassium excretion and would not have prevented this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine, like amlodipine, is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia. Moreover, the combination of drugs from the same class is not recommended for the treatment of hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Torsemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the resorption of potassium in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It can also cause hypokalemia and would exacerbate the thiazide-induced hypokalemia seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has manifestations of hypokalemia (e.g., muscle cramps, weakness, and U waves on ECG). Thiazide diuretics inhibit Na+ reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, which increases K+ excretion and can lead to hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up after elevated blood pressure was noted at his last two visits over the past 6 months. His blood pressure today is 154/90 mm Hg in the right arm and 155/93 mm Hg in the left arm. He agrees to begin treatment with a thiazide diuretic. Which one of the following changes in serum laboratory values is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiazides and most diuretics decrease serum Na+. The diuretic effect of these drugs is due to the increase of Na+ in the renal tubule, which creates an osmotic gradient for fluid to be excreted in the urine.

B) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics increase total serum cholesterol levels, mildly increase low-density lipoproteins, and increase triglyceride levels. Thiazides do not considerably change high-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics increase (rather than decrease) uric acid levels, since they compete for the same binding site in the renal tubule transporters. Furthermore, the diuretic effect of thiazides leads to plasma volume depletion (dehydration) with subsequent hemoconcentration and increase of uric acid.

D) INCORRECT:

Both loop diuretics and thiazides can cause hypokalemia by inhibition of Na+ reabsorption in the distal tubule and resultant increased K+ excretion in the late distal tubule and collecting tubule (via Na+-K+ exchangers); they do not increase potassium levels.

E) CORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics can increase serum calcium levels. Other adverse effects include hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. The inhibition of Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal tubule causes a net urine loss of positive ions such as Na+. This is compensated by renal tubular reabsorption of Ca2+ to maintain electrochemical balance. Thiazides can also be used for the management of osteoporosis and for the prevention of calcium kidney stones.

Key learning point: Thiazide diuretics commonly increase serum calcium while causing hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hyperglycemia, and hyperlipidemia.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.
questions.hint: Thiazide diuretics act by inhibiting NaCl reabsorption in the early distal tubule.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of right knee pain and general malaise for the past 8 hours. He does not remember any trauma to the right knee. He has an 8-year history of osteoporosis. Three years ago, he was diagnosed with primary hypertension and started on a diuretic. On physical examination, the skin above his right knee is erythematous and tender to palpation. Laboratory studies show mild leukocytosis. Arthrocentesis is performed. Analysis of the synovial fluid under polarized light microscopy shows negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. The patient's diuretic most likely acts on which of the following parts of the nephron?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The proximal convoluted tubule is the site of action of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as acetazolamide. Carbonic anhydrase inhibition lowers bicarbonate levels in the blood by increasing excretion in the urine, which leads to acidification of blood pH and can worsen gout. However, this class of drugs is not used for hypertension but for glaucoma, altitude sickness, and cystine stone prophylaxis.

B) INCORRECT:

Osmotic diuretics (e.g., mannitol) work predominantly on the proximal tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle. This group of medications relies on osmosis to pull water into the tubular lumen, which leads to increased urine output. Osmotic diuretics are used in acute cases of cerebral edema and acute angle glaucoma but not to treat hypertension, since they do not promote Na+ excretion in the urine. They also do not play a significant role in uric acid metabolism or the development of gout.

C) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics inhibit the Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the thick ascending loop of Henle. Loop diuretics can also lead to hyperuricemia, but in a patient with hypertension and a history of osteoporosis, a different diuretic is a better choice, as it increases Ca2+ levels. Loop diuretics are not an ideal drug for patients with osteoporosis because they decrease Ca2+ levels by increasing the amount excreted in urine.

D) CORRECT:

The distal convoluted tubule is the site of action for thiazide diuretics. Blockage of Na+-Cl- cotransporters leads to increased diuresis and excretion of sodium. Decreased intracellular sodium levels promote the activity of the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger, which in turn reduces intracellular calcium concentration. This results in increased calcium reabsorption from the lumen via Ca2+ channels leading to hypercalcemia. Because this patient has a history of hypertension and osteoporosis, he was most likely prescribed a thiazide diuretic, which also caused the hyperuricemia that led to an acute gout attack.
Image Description:

A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.

B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.

C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.

D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na+-Cl- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.

E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

E) INCORRECT:

Epithelial Na+ channel blockers work in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts. These drugs are usually referred to as potassium-sparing diuretics, as they can actually cause hyperkalemia. Na+ channel blockers alone are not the first-line treatment for hypertension and do not have a significant influence on Ca2+ blood levels, meaning they are unlikely to have been prescribed to this patient. They also do not play a significant role in uric acid metabolism or the development of gout.

F) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone) directly affect the distal tubule and collecting ducts. They work by competitively binding to aldosterone receptors, leading to decreased Na+ reabsorption and K+ excretion. Indications for aldosterone receptor blockers include volume overload states caused by congestive heart failure, nephrotic syndrome, cirrhosis, and hypertension. Since they have no significant influence on the Ca2+ blood levels, however, a different diuretic was most likely prescribed. They also do not play a significant role in uric acid metabolism or the development of gout.
questions.hint: This patient presents with an acute gout attack of his knee confirmed by negatively birefringent needles on polarized microscopy.
